results.title: For today, for tomorrow: new choices for older Australians
results.creator_credit: Maria Taylor and Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health in association with National Recording Studios Canberra
results.brief_description: Through the lives of five older Australians, this program explores the Commonwealth Governments’ new directions for aged care services. The services featured include Home & Community Care services that allow people to remain in their own homes, the Geriatric Assessment Teams that assist individuals and their families in making informed choices and then co-ordinate the services, and a new range of choices for hostels and nursing homes. Discusses programs that address special needs such as those of older migrants. Narrated by June Salter.

results.title: Go for it!
results.creator_credit: Clayton Jacobson and Barwon Youth Employment Office for the Employment Access Program, Community Services Victoria
results.brief_description: A program aimed at young disadvantaged youth in the labour market, particularly those attending Youth Training Centres, Youth Welfare Services, living in hostels or in the care and custody of Community Services Victoria. Highlights young people succeeding in various jobs and through interviews discusses how they found employment, their expectations and experiences in the workforce.

results.title: Appearances can deceive: offenders with intellectual disabilities
results.creator_credit: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Baker, New South Wales Film Corporation, New South Wales. Premier's Dept. Disability Services Co-ordination Unit and Suzanne Baker Productions
results.brief_description: Designed to improve awareness of intellectually disabled offenders in the criminal justice system, given that this group comprise a disproportionate percentage of both the prison population and juvenile offenders held in institutions. Re-enacts a shop lifting offence by an intellectually disabled youth and follows the case from initial apprehension by the store detective and police interviewing to the arrest and court proceedings. Emphasises the importance of liason with community agencies.
results.title_for_label: Appearances can deceive: offenders with intellectual disabilities
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bob Kingsbury, Suzanne Baker, New South Wales Film Corporation, New South Wales. Premier’s Dept. Disability Services Co-ordination Unit and Suzanne Baker Productions

results.title: In search of a landscape
results.creator_credit: Hannah Dunne and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: The pre-performance preparations by Hannah Dunne and her dance troupe as they practice for their performance of “In search of a landscape”. Hannah describes to the viewer how she arrived at the name for this particular piece. NB: This video was donated by the performer and has a grainy quality. You do not need to adjust your machine.

results.title: Professional Development
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and Institute of Educational Administration
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Case studies in effective schooling”.
Case studiesin effective schooling presents first hand accounts of how individual schools have gone about improving their effectiveness. “Professional development” is the second part in the series and records the manner in which Ivanhoe East Primary School supports its educational program with a coherent, planned program of professional development for its staff.

results.title: Artists in cyberculture
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Cohen, Frances McGivern and Cracked Metal Productions
results.brief_description: Artists record their work at the Third International Symposium on Electronic Art, Sydney, 1992. Through a series of interviews, performance, electronic theatre, this video looks at ways in which artists challenge the emerging technological realm known as “cyberculture”. It also examines issues such as gender, the body, the homogenisation of culture and the social and environmental implications of new technologies. Three of the artists interviewed are Char Davies, Stelarc and Myron Kreuger.

results.title: Concrete city
results.creator_credit: Fabio Cavadini, Mandy King and Frontyard Films
results.brief_description: This thought-provoking film about a small community of working class people who live in the old wharfside Sydney suburb of Pyrmont, brings into question the notion of coummunity participation in major urban development schemes. The development, in this case, involves nothing less than the total destruction of a community and of valuable heritage sites, for the construction of a casino and a whole range of high rise commercial development. The community is “consulted” and “involved”, yet their own suggestions as to how best develop the area are largely ignored.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Fabio Cavadini, Mandy King and Frontyard Films

results.title: 1993 World solar challenge
results.creator_credit: Don Scutt, GMH and Monash University. Mechanical Engineering, Caulfield
results.brief_description: Covers the 1993 Daido Hoxan World Solar Challenge, a race by solar powered cars from Darwin to Adelaide over 3000 kilometres. Includes interviews with the leading teams and technical experts.

results.title: Sir Jack Brabham: The complete history of a motor racing legend
results.creator_credit: Neville Hay and Hay Fisher Productions
results.brief_description: Brabham - one of the great names in motor racing history. A great driver who not only became a household name worldwide during the 1950’s and 60’s for his driving exploits, but who also created a racing team that was still winning in the 1980’s. This story of Sir Jack Brabham, told exclusively in his own words and by close associates including Stirling Moss, Roy Salvadori and and John Cooper. Extensive archival material captures the feel of some glorious motor racing while tracing every step of a truly brilliant career.

results.title: Spitfire over Australia
results.brief_description: During World War II, more than 650 Spitfire aircraft were delivered to the RAAF. This is the story of Colin Pay, who rebuilt one of those magnificent machines, a Vickers Supermarine Spitfire HF Mk VIII built in 1944, from the corroded hulk he acquired in 1982. It is now a superbly restored flying machine. Including some of the best air to air colour footage ever shot of a Spitfire in Australia, and archival footage of Spitfires in Darwin in 1943 and interviews with the pilots who originally flew them, this is the ideal video for avaition enthusiasts!
